chunks.section_name: Highlighting the Advantages of Operating NMC811 Cells to Voltages below 4.20 V Compared to NMC Grades with Lower Ni Content

chunks.text: Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 2023 170 080515

A. Eldesoky, [1] N. Kowalski, [2] and J. R. Dahn [1][,][3][,][z] 1Department of Chemistry, Dalhousie University, Halifax, NS, Canada
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Dalhousie University, Halifax, NS, Canada
3Department of Physics & Atmospheric Science, Dalhousie University, Halifax, NS, Canada Ni-rich Li-ion cells suffer from severe capacity fade at high states of charge (SOC) due to oxygen release and/or lattice volume
collapse. We share long-term cycling results (12000 h) at 40 °C for NMC811, NMC532, and NMC640 cells cycled with different
upper cut-off voltages (UCV), C-rates, and depths of discharge (DOD). We show that cycling to a greater UCV results in more
capacity loss and resistance growth as expected. However, NMC811 suffered from 5–10 times greater resistance growth at 4.20 V
compared to 4.06 V, while the resistance for NMC532 and NMC640 cycled to 4.30 V was roughly twice that of the 4.10 V UCV
cells. This highlights a challenging problem with Ni-rich materials that can be mitigated if the UCV is limited to avoid NMC811
volume change. Finally, we used competitive graphite materials reported in previous work to examine the impact of UCV on the
rate of SEI growth in NMC811 cells, which was found to increase with temperature and UCV, particularly at ⩾4.08 V UCV. We
hope this brief report will highlight the importance of lifetime energy output, rather than initial energy density, and encourage
battery users to limit the UCV of Ni-rich cells when possible.
© 2023 The Author(s). Published on behalf of The Electrochemical Society by IOP Publishing Limited. This is an open access

[1945-7111/aceffd]](https://doi.org/10.1149/1945-7111/aceffd) Manuscript submitted June 2, 2023; revised manuscript received July 20, 2023. Published August 23, 2023. [Supplementary material for this article is available online](https://doi.org/10.1149/1945-7111/aceffd)
chunks.section_name: Highlighting the Advantages of Operating NMC811 Cells to Voltages below 4.20 V Compared to NMC Grades with Lower Ni Content

chunks.text:
[Supplementary material for this article is available online](https://doi.org/10.1149/1945-7111/aceffd) Ni-rich positive electrode materials are attractive due to their
high energy density. [1] However, Ni-rich NMC materials experience a
large lattice volume collapse upon delithiation. [2] This large volume
change can expose fresh, reactive particle surfaces to the electrolyte
which increase the parasitic reactions between the positive electrode
and the electrolyte, increase cell resistance, and result in rapid
capacity fade. [3] Moreover, Ni-rich materials such as NMC811 are
known to release lattice oxygen past 80% state of charge (SOC) that
can result in electrolyte oxidation. [4] While Ni-rich cells cycled to
high SOC benefit from a competitive energy density compared
to other positive electrode materials, the degradation of these materials
eventually results in lower energy output per cycle compared to lower
SOC counterparts. [4][–][6] There have been many strategies employed, with
varying degrees of success, to address these well-known issues with
Ni-rich materials such as the use of coatings, dopants, core-shell
particle design, single crystalline (SC) particle morphologies, and
electrolyte additives. [1][,][5][,][7][–][10] Despite these research efforts, the lifetime of Ni-rich materials is
still compromised at high SOCs. Previous work from our group
looked at the impact of C-rate, depth of discharge (DOD), and upper
cut-off voltage (UCV) on the lifetime of NMC811/Artificial
Graphite (AG) cells. [11] We found that cells operating at top of
charge with a small DOD (i.e., spend more time at high SOCs)
experienced more capacity loss than cells operating with a large
DOD. This was attributed to potential oxygen release/lattice volume
collapse at high SOCs that will be occurring more frequently for
cells cycling in 3.9–4.20 V window, for example. [11] While C-rate and
DOD choice did impact capacity loss, cycling NMC811 past 4.06 V
was far more detrimental than any other factor. [11] If NMC811 cells
are limited to 4.06 V UCV, the resistance growth is minimal and
capacity loss is largely governed by SEI growth only. Therefore, we
explored the impact of negative electrode materials on the lifetime of
NMC811 cells and found a more competitive artificial graphite (AG)
material that outperformed our commonly-used Kaijin AML400
material. [6][,][12] This led us to believe that the use of competitive AG
materials and limiting the volume change in NMC811 cells can yield
chunks.section_name: Highlighting the Advantages of Operating NMC811 Cells to Voltages below 4.20 V Compared to NMC Grades with Lower Ni Content

chunks.text:
ultra-long-lived Ni-rich cells that may be suited for energy storage
applications.
This brief report shares some long-term cycling results from
NMC811, NMC532 and NMC640 cells with the same negative
electrode (Kaijin AML400) to highlight the impact of volume
change on resistance growth of NMC811 cells compared to NMC
grades with lower Ni-content. We also used the competitive AG
material (“AGC”) reported in previous work from our group to
examine the impact of UCV on the rate of SEI growth at 40 °C and
70 °C. With the increasing demand for Li-ion batteries, we believe
taking any measures to prolong cell lifetime to maximize energy
output is important to address the growing energy storage needs and
reducing energy consumption to replace spent cells. [13] Experimental Methods electrolyte additives. Pouch cells and electrolytes.—Machine-made pouch cells were

chunks.text:
Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 2023 170 080515 Figure 1. Checkup cycle capacity loss at t = 12000 h for NMC811, NMC532 and NMC640 cells with the same AG negative electrode. All cycling was at 40 °C
and the lower cut-off voltage was 3.0 V. The UCVs for NMC811 cells were 4.06 or 4.20, while the UCV for NMC532 and NMC640 were 4.10 or 4.30 V. Left
column shows cells cycled with a 25 % DOD, and right column shows cells cycled with 100 % DOD. Cycle number in brackets, UCV, C-rate, and DOD are as
indicated in the panels. C/20 charge-discharge formation cycle at 40.0 ± 0.1 °C between
3.00 and the UCV specified for each cell. All cells were degassed
after formation prior to any further testing. Long-term cycling.—Long-term cycling was done on Neware
cyclers (Shenzhen, China). All cycling conditions are indicated in
Table I below. Periodic, low-rate, capacity check cycles were done
every 500 h or every 50 cycles at 100% DOD and C/10:C/10 or C/
20:C/20 in some cases. The UCVs for NMC532 and NMC640 were
4.10 V or 4.30 V for ease of comparison with internal lab data, and
the UCV for NMC811 were 4.06 V or 4.20 V to avoid the lattice
volume change around 80% SOC, and to trigger it with the higher
UCV. Results and Discussion Comparing NMC811 to NMC532 and NMC640 at different
DODs.—In previous work, we looked at the impact of cycling
conditions (C-rate, DOD, UCV, and temperature) on the lifetime of
SC NMC811/AGA cells. [11] While capacity was impacted by DOD
and C-rate choice, the primary detriment to cell lifetime was

Comparing NMC811 to NMC532 and NMC640 at different
DODs.—In previous work, we looked at the impact of cycling
conditions (C-rate, DOD, UCV, and temperature) on the lifetime of
SC NMC811/AGA cells. [11] While capacity was impacted by DOD
and C-rate choice, the primary detriment to cell lifetime was operating NMC811 cells to an UCV of 4.20 V compared to
4.06 V. Figure S1 shows the discharge capacity (mAh) and normalized ΔV growth for NMC811/AGA cells cycled at 40 °C. The
difference between the average charge and discharge voltage is
“ΔV” in this work and is taken as a. measure of resistance growth in
the cell. The UCV was 4.06 V or 4.20 V and cells were discharged to
25, 50, 75, or 100 % DOD at C/3:C/3. Cycling at or below 4.06 V vs
graphite avoids the lattice volume collapse of NMC811. Figure S1
shows that limiting the UCV to 4.06 V greatly hindered ΔV growth.
The 4.20 V cells showed ∼250 % ΔV growth compared to ∼20 %
for 4.06 V counterparts after 12000 h of cycling at 40 °C. This ΔV
growth will negatively impact the cell’s power and energy output.
While operating Li-ion cells at higher voltages is known to
accelerate capacity loss and resistance growth, NMC811 cells suffer
from severe lattice volume collapse past ∼80 % SOC which greatly
hinders the cell’s performance compared to NMC grades with lower
Ni content. [2][–][4][,][6][,][14] Other grades of NMC can experience some lattice
volume change at high SOCs, this behavior is much more detrimental for Ni-rich positive electrodes. [7] NMC532/AGA and NMC640/AGA cells were cycled at 40 °C to
4.10 V or 4.30 V with 25 % or 100% DOD at C/3:C/3 and 1C:1C,

Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 2023 170 080515 Figure 2. Percent ΔV growth at t = 12000 h for NMC811, NMC532 and NMC640 cells with the same AG negative electrode. All cycling was at 40 °C and the
lower cut-off voltage was 3.0 V. The UCVs for NMC811 cells were 4.06 or 4.20, while the UCV for NMC532 and NMC640 were 4.10 or 4.30 V. Left column
shows cells cycled with a 25 % DOD, and right column shows cells cycled with 100 % DOD. Cycle number in brackets, UCV, C-rate, and DOD are as indicated
in the panels. and the results were compared to previous NMC811 data. [11] Figure 1
shows the capacity loss from the checkup cycles at t = 12000 h for
NMC811, NMC532 and NMC640 cells. C-rate, DOD, and UCV are
indicated for each panel. Figures S2–S3 show the discharge capacity
and ΔV growth vs time for the NMC532 and NMC640 cells. The
NMC532 and NMC640 cells cycled at 1 C:1 C show that high DOD
results in more capacity fade, which is consistent with previous
reports on the impact of DOD in cell lifetime. [15][–][17] Similar trends can
be seen in NMC640 cells cycled at C/3:C/3 with a 4.30 V UCV, but
differences due to DOD were very small for NMC532 and NMC640
cycled to a 4.10 V UCV. In contrast, NMC811 in Figs. 1a–1b show
that 25 % DOD cells actually had more capacity loss compared to
100 % DOD, which we attributed to longer residence time at high
SOCs when the DOD is only 25 % (i.e., cycling in the 3.9–4.20 V
range) as discussed in our previous work. [11] While NMC640 cells showed poor retention at 1 C:1 C, this
performance can be greatly improved by tailoring the electrolyte
additive to improve high-rate performance. In fact, NMC640 cells
cycled at 4.30 V and 1 C:1 C in Fig. 1d did not cycle for more than
500 h and showed severe Li plating (see Fig. S3). Here, 2VC1DTD

While NMC640 cells showed poor retention at 1 C:1 C, this
performance can be greatly improved by tailoring the electrolyte
additive to improve high-rate performance. In fact, NMC640 cells
cycled at 4.30 V and 1 C:1 C in Fig. 1d did not cycle for more than
500 h and showed severe Li plating (see Fig. S3). Here, 2VC1DTD was used throughout for consistency so additives that result in
smaller RCT compared to VC may be more suitable for NMC640
cells. [18][,][19] Overall, NMC532 cells had the best capacity retention. At
low UCV, NMC640 had less capacity fade compared to NMC811
(Figs. 1a–1b) but performed similar to NMC811 at high UCV
(Figs. 1c–1d).
Figure 2 shows the ΔV growth at t = 12000 h for the cells in
Fig. 1. Low UCV cells in the top row show small ΔV growth after
12000 h. NMC640 had more severe ΔV growth at 1 C:1 C and C/3:
C/3 for both DODs compared to NMC532. The NMC811 cells
showed the largest ΔV growth at 4.20 V followed by NMC640 and
NMC532. The severe ΔV growth for NMC811 shown in Fig. 2 will
drastically impact the power density of these cells, therefore keeping
the UCV at or below 4.06 V is critical for NMC811 cells. Even
though cycling to a high UCV increased capacity loss for all cells,
NMC811 cells were the only ones to suffer from a drastic increase in
resistance. Despite small differences in capacity loss (<5 %)
between NMC81 and NMC532/640 in Figs. 1c–1d, the NMC811
cells tested to 4.2 V show 3–8 times as much ΔV growth compared
to the other NMC grades tested to 4.3 V.

Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 2023 170 080515 Figure 3. (a)-(b) Discharge capacity (mAh), (c)-(d) normalized capacity, and (e)-(f) normalized ΔV for NMC811/AGC cells cycled to different UCVs at 70 and
40 °C with C/3:C/3 rates. Rate of SEI growth as a function of temperature and UCV for
NMC811.—To further demonstrate the impact of UCV on capacity
loss, NMC811/AGC cells were cycled to 4.04, 4.06, 4.08, 4.10, and
4.20 V UCV at 40 °C or 70 °C. Cells were not cycled at 70 °C with
a 4.20 V UCV. The AGC material here was used because it was
more competitive than AGA as shown previously, [6] so we wanted to
see the impact of low SOC cycling and competitive graphite material
on capacity loss. Figure 3 shows the discharge capacity (mAh),
normalized capacity, and normalized ΔV vs cycle number for
NMC811/AGC cells with different UCVs. Despite the small
difference of 60 mV between the 4.04 and 4.10 V cells, the 4.04 V
cell lost 10 % capacity and its resistance increased by 5% at 70 °C
after 400 cycles, compared to 15 % capacity loss and 30% resistance
growth at 4.10 V UCV. Similar trends can be seen after 2500 cycles
at 40 °C, where increasing the UCV resulted in more fade and ΔV
growth. The importance of limiting the UCV is not just to improve
capacity retention, but also to keep the resistance growth under
control to avoid compromising the power capabilities of the cells. In
addition to the improved resistance growth at low UCVs, Fig. 3b
suggests that 4.04 V cells may have greater lifetime energy output
compared to 4.20 V.
NMC811 cells operating below 4.20 V show small resistance
growth during cycling and the capacity loss is primarily Li loss due
to SEI growth. [6][,][11] Therefore, the rate of capacity loss as a function of time will likely follow the simple square-root time model as
described in previous work by Broussely and co-workers. [20][,][21] The
square-root time model assumes that SEI thickness increases with _t_, where _t_ is time, according to the following equation: _Q t_ ( ) = _Qo_ (1          - _A t_ ) [ ]1

_Q t_ ( ) = _Qo_ (1          - _A t_ ) [ ]1 where _Q t_ ( ) is capacity at time _t_, _Qo_ is initial capacity, and _A_ is a
proportionality term. The term _A_ will increase with rate of SEI
growth.
Figure 4 shows the measured and calculated capacity loss for
NMC811/AGC cells cycled at 40 °C with 2VC1DTD and different
UCVs along with the residuals from the fit (difference between
measured and calculated capacity). The C/20:C/20 capacity check
cycles were fitted here. Figure S4 shows measured and calculated
capacity loss for the 70 °C cells shown in Fig. 3. For both
temperatures, the square root time model fits the measured data
quite well as seen in the residual plots for voltages below 4.20 V.
This is expected for cells where capacity loss is only due to SEI
growth and the concentration of Li in the negative electrode
overhang is small since the cells are cycled to 100 % DOD. [22] However, the residuals are larger for the 4.20 V cells since the
increasing ΔV contributes to capacity fade on top of SEI growth, so
the square-root time model is not a perfect fit in this case.

Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 2023 170 080515 Figure 4. Measured and calculated capacity loss for NMC811/AGC cells cycled to 4.04 V, 4.06 V, 4.08 V, 4.10 V, and 4.20 V UCV at 40 °C. Figure 5. A parameter vs UCV for NMC811/AGC cells cycled at 40 °C or 70 °C. All cycling was done at C/3:C/3 and the lower cut-off voltage was 3.0 V for all
cells. The 40 °C cells had about 2500 cycles (1500 for 4.20 V UCV) and the 70 °C cells had about 400 cycles.

Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 2023 170 080515 Figure 6. Discharge energy (mWh) vs time (hours) for NMC811/AGC cells cycling at (a) 70 °C or (b) 40 °C with different UCVs. All cycling was done at C/3:
C/3. Circles shows the measured data and solid lines are extrapolated discharge energy trajectories based on Eq. 1. The solid lines terminate at 80 % of the initial
discharge energy for each cell. (c)-(d) cumulative energy output (Wh) and (e)-(f) normalized energy output normalized to the initial energy at end of life (i.e., 80
% of the initial discharge energy). Figure 5 shows the extracted A parameter vs UCV for the 40 °C
and 70 °C cells. Note the difference in y-axis scale for the 40 °C and
70 °C data, At 40 °C, the A term increases slightly from 4.04 V to
4.06 V. There is a clear increase in SEI growth at 4.08 V and 4.10 V,
consistent with the differences in capacity fade and ΔV in Fig. 3.
When the cell is cycled to 4.20 V UCV, the rate of SEI growth
increases by nearly two-fold. Similarly for 70 °C, the rate of SEI
growth linearly increases from 4.04 V to 4.08 V and spikes at
4.10 V. At 4.10 V, the A term is nearly 30 % greater than 4.08 V
despite only 20 mV difference in voltage. Lowering the UCV is
therefore critical for the longevity of NMC811 cells.
Finally, we wanted to consider the lifetime energy output as a
function of temperature and UCV. Figure 6 shows the discharge
energy (mWh) vs time (hours) for the cells in Fig. 3, and the total
energy and normalized energy outputs at 70 °C and 40 °C. Using the
square-root time model to fit the measured data (see Eq. 1), we
extrapolated the discharge energy trajectory for the different UCVs
up until reaching 80 % of the initial discharge energy (taken as end
of life here). From there, assuming that one C/3:C/3 cycle is
completed every 6 h, we took the sum of discharge energy output
from each cycle to get the cumulative energy output over the cell’s
lifetime. The total energy was then divided by the initial discharge

energy to get the normalized energy output. The results in Fig. 6
assume that Li loss will continue to follow the square-root time
model until end of life and does not consider any failures mitigated
by the cell form factor and/or mechanical degradation of the cell
components. Note from Fig. 4 above that the residuals from the
square-root time model for the 4.20 V cells were larger than the
lower voltage ones. In Fig. 6b, the discharge energy data for the
4.20 V cells shows a slightly more linear trajectory than the fitted
data in the solid lines. This is due to the resistance growth
experienced at higher UCV which impacts the quality of the fit.
This means that estimates of cumulative stored energy for the 4.2 V
cells tested at 40 °C will be overestimates based on only the square
root time model.
Figures 6a–6b show that, at 70 °C and 40 °C, the time it takes the
cell to reach 80 % of the initial discharge energy decreases as the
UCV increases (see solid lines). Looking at Figs. 6c–6d, the
cumulative energy output at end of life decreases with increasing
UCV at both temperatures, with a sharp drop in output going from
4.10 V to 4.20 V in Fig. 6d. The energy output for the 4.04 V cells in
Fig. 6d was nearly three times that of the 4.20 V cells, despite the
initial energy penalty seen in Fig. 6b. Similar trends can be seen in
the normalized energy outputs in Figs. 6e–6f.

Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 2023 170 080515 Figure 7. Normalized ΔV vs cumulative energy output (Wh) for NMC811/AGC cells cycled at 40 °C or 70 °C. All cycling was done at C/3:C/3 and the lower
cut-off voltage was 3.0 V for all cells. The 40 °C cells had about 2500 cycles (1500 for 4.20 V UCV) and the 70 °C cells had about 400 cycles. The dashed line
shows the point where ΔV growth is at 20%. Figure 7 shows normalized ΔV vs cumulative discharge energy
output (Wh) at 70 °C and 40 °C. The dashed line represents a
hypothetical scenario where only 20 % resistance growth is allowed
for a given application. Here, we can clearly see that as we increase the
UCV, the 20 % resistance growth threshold (or any other limit on ΔV
growth) will be reached at smaller energy outputs at both temperatures.
At 70 °C, ΔV steadily increases with UCV. However, at 40 °C,
the ΔV growth is similar for both 4.04 and 4.06 V cells at the time of
writing. The trends at 40 °C are likely to be the same as 70 °C but
after more cycling as seen in Figs. 6c-6d. The results in Figs. 6–7
suggest that limiting the UCV for NMC811 cells can be very costeffective when considering the initial cost of the cell and its lifetime
energy output, rather than initial $/kWh. While this usage scheme may
not be suitable for applications where high-energy is more important
than lifetime, we believe purpose-built NMC811 (or Ni-rich cells,
more broadly) that are balanced to operate at low UCVs can be
important in stationary energy storage applications and in applications
where cells are continuously exposed to high temperatures. Conclusions

Conclusions This short communication shares some long-term cycling results
on NMC811, NMC532, and NMC640 cells cycled at different DODs
and C-rates for 12000 h at 40 °C. All cells had similar construction
with an identical AG negative electrode and electrolyte. In this work,
we showed that NMC811 cells suffer from a severe resistance growth
when cycled past 4.06 V due to the large lattice volume collapse that
the positive electrode material experiences. This is further demonstrated in Fig. 3, where increasing the UCV by even 10–30 mV
resulted in a dramatic increase in capacity loss and resistance growth
at 40 and 70 °C. In contrast to the other NMC grades with lower Ni
content, 4.3 V cycling resulted in doubling the cell’s resistance (at the
most) for NMC532 and NMC640 compared to 4.10 V. However,
NMC811 cells cycled to 4.20 V experienced 5-10 times the resistance
growth that was seen in the same cells cycled to 4.06 V. We believe
this highlights an ongoing challenge with Ni-rich materials that will
greatly impact the cell lifetime and power capabilities. Therefore,
limiting the UCV when possible is a simple and important measure
for battery consumers to consider when operating Ni-rich cells.
Additionally, Ni-rich cells that are balanced to 4.04 or 4.06 V will
recover energy density compared to Ni-rich cells that are balanced to
4.2 V and operated to 4.04 or 4.06 V. Acknowledgments The authors acknowledge financial support from the NSERC/
Tesla Canada Industrial Research Chair program. A.E. thanks Vanier CGS, Killam Foundation, and O’Brien Foundation for financial
support. The authors thank Dr. Michael Metzger (Dalhousie
University) for his valuable feedback on the manuscript. ORCID References 1 J U Choi, N Voronina, Y.-K Sun, and S.-T Myung, “Recent progress and
perspective of advanced high-energy co-less ni-rich cathodes for li-ion batteries:
[yesterday, today, and tomorrow.” Adv Energy Mater., 10, 2002027 (2020).](https://doi.org/10.1002/aenm.202002027)
2 K Märker, P J Reeves, C Xu, K J Griffith, and C P Grey, “Evolution of
structure and lithium dynamics in LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 (NMC811) Cathodes
[during electrochemical cycling.” Chem

P Grey, “Evolution of
structure and lithium dynamics in LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 (NMC811) Cathodes
[during electrochemical cycling.” Chem Mater., 31, 2545 (2019).](https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00140)
3 J Li, L E Downie, L Ma, W Qiu, and J R Dahn, “Study of the failure
mechanisms of LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 cathode material for lithium ion batteries.”
[J Electrochem Soc., 162, A1401 (2015).](https://doi.org/10.1149/2.1011507jes)
